5/n What do we study when we study protocol arbitrage? 

- Acquisition and liquidation of assets. 
- Spreads.
- Opportunity discovery. 
- Cryptoeconomics of complex protocols. 
- Related assets. 
- Staking and borrowing rates.

1119276443207380992.text: 4/n I think the number of protocol arbitrage opportunities will grow very large. The opportunity set of arbitrage is a combinatorial function of the number of available markets (very steep). But in crypto, the number of markets is itself an exponential function of protocols!

1119276439382175745.text:
3/n Things get more interesting in protocol-protocol arbitrage, which is when e.g. your exchange becomes a dex protocol, or another protocol where you can exchange assets.

Imagine buying an asset from a bonding curve and selling it (or a related asset) to another curve.

1119276436081336320.text:
2/n In protocol-exchange arbitrage we acquire an asset on-protocol cheaply and sell it on an exchange.

PoW mining can be an example of this kind of arbitrage, but the more interesting examples deal with on-chain acquisition or conversion of assets.

1119276429974417408.text:
1/n In traditional finance, arbitrage typically buys an asset on one exchange and sells to another.

In crypto, protocol-exchange or protocol-protocol arbitrage is possible.

1114519192173252610.text: The natural mechanism that begins to form in this context is delegation. Delegation allows stakeholders to deputize and elevate certain individuals into positions of responsibility, and the trade off is that those individuals begin to retain more influence in the organization.

1114519191095336960.text:
The flat DAOs we see today suffer from massive dispersion of responsibility issues, which get exponentially worse with every new marginal member. 

DoR is when everyone is paralyzed because they assume that someone else is moving the progress of the DAO forward. But no one is.

1114519189874720773.text:
DAOs have low engagement issues. 

One approach to address these issues has been quorumless voting. This is a good approach, and does increase the liveness (ability to move forward) of DAOs.

But this in itself is not enough.

Overall, valuing governance tokens by relative influence over votes opens up a new class of valuation conundrums:

1000 users @ 1 unit of voting power each are less influential than 1 user @ 1000 shares. So 1 unit of the currency is worth 0, but together their value increases...

1112778775585083397.text: 6. A @MolochDAO member who increases their shares to 200 will exert elevated influence over other members. Their decisiveness will in fact be more than 2x the decisiveness of 100-share stakes.

1112778774163193857.text:
4. The 24-share member should ragequit to get value or increase to at least 100 shares in order to conserve their decisiveness. 

5. An existing member looking to increase their stake should not increase by less than 75 shares, or they will not get any benefit in influence.

1112778772493864963.text: 3. If a new, 100-share member joins the DAO, the 24-share stake will be rendered worthless and will never decide a vote because the number of 100-share tokenholders will be odd.

1112778770723766274.text:
1. The summoner share of 1 unit, by itself, has no power and is worth 0.

2. Today, the 24-share member has just as much influence as a 100-share member despite having a lower-valuation stake.

1112778769339727873.text:
Today, @MolochDAO, has 24 members — 22 have 100 voting shares, 1 member has 24 shares, and the summoner (@ameensol) has an account with 1 share. 

Decisiveness analysis produces the following results for @MolochDAO.

1112778767859154950.text: Decisiveness has many other interesting properties, including enabling analysis on what governance stakes are advantageous and being able to measure the “dictatorship-ness” of a system.

1112778766433095680.text: But in this allocation of tokens, {100, 100, 100, 1}, the 1-unit token holder will never influence a single vote. The decisiveness, and therefore value, of his stake is 0.

1112778765090869248.text: In fact, in this governance system having 1 unit of voting power is just as good as having 100 units. In terms of influence, *every* token holder can overturn the outcome in 50% of possible scenarios.

1112778763752935426.text: For example, imagine a system with the following token allocations: {100, 100, 1}. Surprisingly, the 1-unit stake is actually pretty powerful in voting scenarios where the two 100-units token holders are at odds and acts as a tie breaker.

1112778762427482113.text:
Intuitively, the decisiveness of a stake relative to a token distribution is the expected % of the time that this stake’s vote (or lack thereof) can overturn the outcome of a proposal. 

The properties of decisiveness are based on discrete partitioning & are somewhat surprising.

1112778761227915265.text:
The central question I am trying to answer is the following. Given a governance token distribution, how do we quantify the influence that a particular token holder’s stake exerts over the governance process?

To answer this, I define a measure called “decisiveness”.

1109094903248834561.text:
The takeaway is this: power laws happen because of network effects. In a world of many interoperable open networks, network effects are diminished. 

There *is* a network effect in d-networks. But long-term, it is in standards, not particular assets or network instances. /end

1109094902242136065.text: Some networks will be stubborn and will increase switching costs artificially to keep network effect—eg, a network will require value accrual to its own token for interoperability. We’ll see, but good chance they get serious competition from consortia of non-stubborn networks.

1109094900660871168.text: Once we attain some basic standards (like WASM), switching networks technologically becomes relatively cheap (perhaps like switching REST APIs). If two networks interoperate (ie share standards, are pegged), then the opportunity costs are mitigated as well.

1109094899541069830.text: However, in a world of commodity networks and interoperability, the real costs and the opportunity costs of switching networks are quite low.

1109094898278559744.text:
In essence, the concept of “switching costs” defines how sticky some product or service is, and also defines the strength of network effect. 

Switching costs can be real physical costs (costs of development, exit penalties); or opportunity costs (eg leaving behind liquidity).

1109094897125130241.text:
It’s become pretty clear that the decentralization space is poised for scalability-by-interoperability and app-dedicated networks. 

In that world, long-term, power law analyses of individual networks and their network effects, IMO, break down dramatically.

1109094895648677893.text:
If we regard one asset as being of one chain, then IMO almost certainly not: there is not enough throughput at scale.

If we can show there is an asset which can do it across chains (eg atoms across hubs, ETH 2.0 across shards), then it becomes more probable.

1109094894210084869.text:
Investors try to figure out if “networks follow power laws” in txs to see if they should invest in a particular network. 

That’s good, but the more precise question is: does the set of assets that captures the value of blockchain txs follow a power law in value capture?

1098713440011591686.text: 4/Decentralized networks become participant-owned infinitely competitive public goods.

1098713438170333185.text:
3/Our current operating system requires the extraction of positive margin from customers to compensate the business owners.

However, decentralization provides a new operating system.

It collapses the owners and customers into a single owner-customer.

1098713436584841219.text:
2/The smaller the margin you have, the more competitive you are. 

(That’s why there is a competitive “race to the bottom” in commodity markets.)

If you can get 0 margin, you become infinitely competitive.

But 0 margin is incompatible with our current economic operating system.

1098713435146203137.text:
1/Margin is the difference between the revenue and costs of a business.

Early or poorly operating businesses have negative margin.

Well-performing businesses have positive margin.

Highly competitive businesses have small positive margin and scale (Amazon).

1090418073834868737.text: 10/Finally, we need a coordination mechanism that aligns the incentives of liquidity providers — and what better coordination mechanism than a DAO?

1090418072119332864.text: 9/Second, we get compliance strategy; that could mean blocking relevant countries and/or ensuring that the orderbook only trades compliant assets and/or structuring in a way that diffuses exchange classification and/or finding a way of safely financing licenses prior to traction.

1090418069019729925.text: 8/Not a proprietary order book, not a trading standard, but an *actual* massive, distributed, open, p2p order book. I think this can look like a basic p2p off-chain eventually consistent store (and there are a lot of technical problems this presents, which are not trivial).

1090418066788413440.text: 7/I think the winning strategy in dexes might have elements of the following. First, we create the *opportunity* to build massive network effects on dexes. Since network effect = liquidity, this means we have to build a large, distributed order book.

1090418064611520515.text: 6/Furthermore, we got some guidance and with no liquidity, we had no revenue and therefore no defensible business model to justify the risk of licenses.

1090418062346596352.text: 5/Ultimately the network effect of an exchange is liquidity. But what we built was a bunch of fragmented and, at times, non-interoperable (because of the lack of cross-chain interoperability) silos. So we lost network effect.

14/THEME THREE: How does #DecentralizedGoverance and #DisputeResolution actually mesh with the real world?

Also a topic often ignored by #blockchain. Yet there is *a lot* to be learned from the way that real jurisdictions handle the decentralization issues of the internet.

1089901077615575045.text: 13/To get a sense of the difficulty of the on-chain space, recall the 2016 "TheDAO Report" by @el33th4xor which identified over 10 possible attacks on the on-chain governance system of #TheDAO.https://docs.google.com/document/u/2/d/10kTyCmGPhvZy94F7VWyS-dQ4lsBacR2dUgGTtV98C40/edit …

1089901076306898944.text: 12/@AragonProject specifically is contemplating on-chain governance and voting systems with dispute resolution.https://blog.aragon.org/aragon-network-jurisdiction-part-1-decentralized-court-c8ab2a675e82/ …

1089901074322997253.text:
11/Most #DecentralizedGovernance projects have not even gotten to this kind of "formal" solution, but thinking this way may indeed prove useful as demonstrated the paper "Crypto Public Choice" by @chrisberg, et al.

http://chrisberg.org/2018/08/crypto-public-choice/ …

1089901071252762625.text: 10/In fact, governance in general, as studied from a mathematical lens, is *really hard*. There is 200+ years of research on social choice & voting theory, rife with impossibility proofs and trilemmas. Some examples and references here:https://twitter.com/jbrukh/status/929425644458561541 …

1089901069927370755.text: 9/There is *a lot* to say on these topics. Both @VitalikButerin (https://vitalik.ca/general/2017/12/17/voting.html …) and @VladZamfir (https://medium.com/@Vlad_Zamfir/against-on-chain-governance-a4ceacd040ca …) have variously advocated for #OffChainGovernance.

1089901068186726400.text:
8/THEME TWO: How does #DecentralizedGovernance and #DisputeResolution actually work?

Should it be on-chain or off? How does a system philosophically approach the tradeoff between immutability and practical recourse in a system? Is DR practical in a decentralized context?

1089901066488037376.text: 7/Remember #TheDAO from 2016? $DAO tokens were, quite literally, exit rights. This lead to a cryptoeconomic bug that caused TheDAO to "leak Ether" until it (may have) eventually evaporated.https://blog.coinfund.io/jentzsch-radiation-the-dao-is-very-slowly-leaking-ether-1fd84171d52e …

1089901064751665152.text: 6/One criticism of the "exit rights" model is that it doesn't actually *solve* valuation, it simply punts the question to the underlying (crypto)asset. However, #ExitRightsValuation is pleasantly quantitative and all the T&Cs are codified on-chain, making them ripe for analysis.

1089901063061286914.text: 5/Another model is that of "exit rights", described by @lkngtn at #RabbitholeTalks: a DAO's tokens often entitle holders to *underlying value* held by the organization and subject to T&Cs. Check out the talk (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eCImhv2fwWI … ) and slides (https://www.slideshare.net/OlgaCoinFund/aragon-by-luke-duncan-at-coinfund-rabbithole-talks …).

1089901061786226688.text: 4/@PhilJBonello has put forward the only *quantitative* treatment that I can find which describes that the value of a governance token as being proportional to "the net cost of forking. . .the network" and actually calculates it.https://hackernoon.com/a-framework-for-valuing-governance-tokens-0x-49d2cf2ef5bc …

1089901060414730240.text: 3/There are actually not too many *actionable* models in this space that I can find. But there are some. . .

1089901059206799362.text:

Token models have "eroded" somewhat these past few years: it's hard to make a token accrue value! But governance is being touted as one of the few activities fundamentally valuable to a network. How does this actually work?

1082807985003528192.text: 13/Thanks to @lkngtn for diving deep into Aragon Courts and the @AragonProject dispute resolution process. Some great thinking happening on this team!

1082807983648792581.text: 12/Is there secret voting for jurors? Potentially; it can be done with multiparty computation or a commit-reveal, to prevent the on-chain frontrunning of votes.

1082807982080036865.text: 11/Courts generate revenues. Standard fees for DR are split between Aragon Network and Jurors. Dispute fees are split among jurors for that dispute.

1082807980066828295.text: 10/How does the system protect from Sybil attacks of jurors? There is a fork choice which uses futarchy to disincentivize that behavior. (A lot more details here, too long to write down in the margin. ;)

1082807978779131905.text: 9/Aragon Court has a process with jurors and appeals which can resolve disputes on chain.

1082807975004327937.text: 8/Organizations create proposal agreements with human readable terms, a collateral deposit, and arbiter (Aragon Court by default).pic.twitter.com/82DiRgfsKT

1082807912337154048.text: 7/“Is governance valuable?” If the rights & privileges granted by tokens are valuable, so is the governance of those rights. “Upgradeability” is valuable. “Exit assurance” is valuable.

1080884867095822336.text: From a blockchain perspective, it does matter that lending protocols run w/o central servers for no particular beneficiary (versus a bank). A much superior set of efficiencies and *incentives* such that a lending product works better and is less misaligned with its customer.

1080884866215014400.text: From a blockchain perspective, it doesn't directly matter why a bank is centralized, though arguably it's not about economies of scale or efficiencies. It's arguably much more about regulatory moats and a bank's custody of massive pools of capital.

1080884865195823109.text: Never have I ever heard a lot of analysis devoted to "causes" of centralization, such as regulation. But can we honestly say there is a "truth" or "one cause"? Probably not. Centralization is likely a result of many factors, including regulation *and* economies of scale.

1080884863501303808.text: Thanks for the interesting thread. However, IMO, there's not much of a "leap of logic" required. 1074873125819613184.text: Four, participants in networks are compensated in proportion to their risk. It's not even close, between: (a) a super high risk seed investor who invested capital before the network was built; (b) a cryptoinvestor who bootstrapped and took on the risk of the alpha network. . .

1074873125039468545.text: That said, d-networks significantly lower entry barries compared to things like the economic elite games of the traditional financial system, nevertheless. It's not even a comparison. Having to learn some Python vs. being a billionaire represents massive progress in access, IMO.

1074873124154413058.text: Three, the value proposition of d-networks is not egalitarianism, though that's a worthy experiment and someone should try it. The value proposition of d-networks is, broadly, digital efficiency any way that's achieved (including potentially dictatorship).

1074873123298783232.text: Two, creating a network that forces a particularly low Gini coefficient is just as pointless as creating one which forces a particularly high one. Networks should over time converge, through forking and governance, to the optimal Gini that make them function well.
